description: From Middle English hevy, heviȝ, from Old English hefiġ, hefeġ, hæfiġ (“heavy; important, grave, severe, serious; oppressive, grievous; slow, dull”), from Proto-West Germanic *habīg (“heavy, hefty, weighty”), from Proto-Germanic *habīgaz (“heavy, hefty, weighty”), from Proto-Indo-European *keh₂p- (“to take, grasp, hold”).

entries.meaning: (of a physical object) Having great weight.
(of a topic) Serious, somber.
Not easy to bear; burdensome; oppressive.
examples: heavy yokes, expenses, undertakings, trials, news, etc.

entries.meaning: (Britain, slang, dated) Good.
examples: This film is heavy.

entries.meaning: (dated, late 1960s, 1970s, US) Profound.
examples: The Moody Blues are, like, heavy.

entries.meaning: (of a rate of flow) High, great.
examples: The ovarian response to gonadotropic hormones may be erratic at first, so that irregular or heavy bleeding sometimes occurs

entries.meaning: (slang) Armed.
examples: Come heavy, or not at all.

entries.meaning: (of music) Loud, distorted, or intense.
examples: Metal is heavier than rock.

entries.meaning: (of weather) Hot and humid.
(of a person) Doing the specified activity more intensely than most other people.
examples: He was a heavy sleeper, a heavy eater and a heavy smoker – certainly not an ideal husband.

entries.meaning: (of the eyes) With eyelids difficult to keep open due to tiredness.
(of food) High in fat or protein; difficult to digest.
examples: Cheese-stuffed sausage is too heavy to eat before exercising.

entries.meaning: Of great force, power, or intensity; deep or intense.
examples: it was a heavy storm;  a heavy slumber in bed;  a heavy punch

entries.meaning: Laden to a great extent.
examples: his eyes were heavy with sleep;  she was heavy with child

entries.meaning: Laden with that which is weighty; encumbered; burdened; bowed down, either with an actual burden, or with grief, pain, disappointment, etc.
examples: Seating himselfe within a darkesome cave, / (Such places heavy Saturnists doe crave,) / Where yet the gladsome day was never seene  […]

entries.meaning: Slow; sluggish; inactive; or lifeless, dull, inanimate, stupid.
examples: a heavy gait, looks, manners, style, etc.
a heavy writer or book

entries.meaning: Impeding motion; cloggy; clayey.
examples: a heavy road; a heavy soil

entries.meaning: Not raised or leavened.
examples: heavy bread

entries.meaning: (of wines or spirits) Having much body or strength.
(obsolete) With child; pregnant.
(physics) Containing one or more isotopes that are heavier than the normal one.
(petroleum) Having high viscosity.
(finance) Of a market: in which the price of shares is declining.
examples: The very low prices of brandy, and the continuance of a heavy market for such a length of time, have begun to attract buyers;  […]

entries.meaning: (nautical, military) Heavily-armed.

definitionGroups.group: (aviation, of an aircraft) Having a relatively high takeoff weight and payload,

entries.meaning: especially, having a maximum takeoff weight exceeding 300,000 tons, as almost all widebodies do, generating high wake turbulence.

adverbs.description: heavy (comparative more heavy, superlative most heavy)

entries.meaning: In a heavy manner; weightily; heavily; gravely.
examples: heavy laden with their sins

entries.meaning: (colloquial, nonstandard) To a great degree; greatly.
(India, colloquial) very
(slang) A villain or bad guy; the one responsible for evil or aggressive acts.
examples: With his wrinkled, uneven face, the actor always seemed to play the heavy in films.

entries.meaning: (slang) A doorman, bouncer or bodyguard.
examples: A fight started outside the bar but the heavies came out and stopped it.

entries.meaning: (journalism, slang, chiefly in the plural) A newspaper of the quality press.
examples: The comment may be offered here that the 'heavies' have been the Design Award's principal scorers, both in the overall bronze plaque days and, since, in the Daily/Sunday Class 1.

entries.meaning: (aviation) A relatively large multi-engined aircraft.

verbs.description: heavy (third-person singular simple present heavies, present participle heavying, simple past and past participle heavied)

entries.meaning: (often with "up") To make heavier.
examples: They piled their goods on the donkey's back, heavying up an already backbreaking load.

entries.meaning: To sadden.
(Australia, New Zealand, informal) To use power or wealth to exert influence on, e.g., governments or corporations; to pressure.
examples: The union was well known for the methods it used to heavy many businesses.

adjectives.description: heavy (comparative more heavy, superlative most heavy)

entries.meaning: Having the heaves.
examples: a heavy horse
